item.title: DealBook Summit: Reckoning with the ‘New Normal’
item.description: At this year’s DealBook Summit, there was an understanding that in the Trump era, business runs through the White house like never before.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin
item.media:credit: KLAWE RZECZY

item.title: From the DealBook Summit: Industry Leaders Share Their Insights
item.description: Representing a variety of public and private sectors, guests from technology and finance to education and the artsparticipated in a lunchtime discussion designed to spark conversation around critical questions of the day.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Experts in business and politics gathered last week at the DealBook Summit in New York.

item.title: DealBook Summit: In a Tumultuous Era, Global Alliances and Practices Are Upended
item.description: While President Trump has made positive moves, panelists on a DealBook task force pointed to Ukraine, Venezuela and, especially, China as serious missteps.
item.dc:creator: Julie Ho
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants in a task force titled “The Global Reorder” included, from left, Samantha Power, Ehud Barak, Senator Chris Coons, Nicholas Kristof, Dr. Mark T. Esper, Fareed Zakaria, Avril Haines and David H. Petraeus.

item.title: DealBook Summit: Business Executives Share Tips for Leadership
item.description: Executives on a DealBook Summit task force panel said fear was not the way to build teams capable of navigating difficult times.
item.dc:creator: Leslie Wayne
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants in a task force titled “The New Rules for Leadership” included, from left, Alex Chriss, Beth Ford, Bob Jordan, David Brooks, Ynon Kreiz, Emma Walmsley and Pete Nordstrom.

item.title: A DealBook Task Force Grapples With Media Trust and Biases
item.description: Legacy journalists on a DealBook Summit panel warned about interference from President Trump, while panelists from new media said he is just the “coroner” for a field that had already lost credibility.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants in a DealBook task force panel had a lively debate about trust and the media. From left, Amna Nawaz, Charlamagne tha God, Ben Shapiro, the moderator Michael Barbaro, Jon Favreau, Andrew Schulz, Stephanie Ruhle and David Remnick.

item.title: DealBook Summit: Education Leaders Feel the Weight of Preparing Graduates for a New World
item.description: Leaders of colleges and universities on a panel at the DealBook Summit said other challenges they face include government pressure and preparing graduates for a new world.
item.dc:creator: Alina Tugend
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seven presidents and chancellors gathered at last week’s DealBook Summit task force on higher education: from left, Carmen Twillie Ambar, Sian Leah Beilock, Jonathan Levin, the panel moderator Jodi Kantor, Ron Daniels, John B. King, Daniel Diermeier and James Harris.

item.title: Takeaways from the Fed meeting.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: A Surrogacy Firm Told Parents-to-Be Their Money Was Safe. Suddenly, It Vanished.
item.description: Surro Connections held itself out as a reliable business. Now, clients have lost as much as tens of thousands of dollars meant to compensate women carrying their pregnancies.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: As the Price of Beef Soars, Restaurants Are in ‘Code Red’ Mode
item.description: Midpriced steakhouses and fine-dining establishments are trying to figure out how to cover their rising costs without scaring away customers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Hunter McRae for The New York Times
item.media:description: Restaurants that specialize in steak, like Halls Chophouse in Charleston, S.C., are feeling the same sticker shock from beef prices as consumers in grocery stores.

item.title: Holiday spending shows effects of an uneven economy.
item.description: Discount and higher-end retailers have reported stronger sales from consumers who are hunting for the best deals and long-lasting items.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Many consumers are gravitating toward retailers that promise what they need most: low prices.

item.title: A divided Fed is meeting with incomplete data.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Data on consumer prices, though months out of date, suggests inflation remains above the Federal Reserve’s long-run target of 2 percent.

item.title: How to Read the Fed’s ‘Dot Plot’ Projections Like a Pro
item.description: The forecasts will offer a glimpse of the path for policy at a highly uncertain moment for economy — and the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: When the Federal Reserve releases its Summary of Economic Projections each quarter, Fed watchers focus on one part in particular: the dot plot.

item.title: What the Fed’s Rate Decision Means for Loans, Credit Cards, Mortgages and More
item.description: See how the central bank’s interest rate stance influences car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mortgage rates have been trending lower on expectations of a slowing economy.

item.title: Trump’s Search for Powell’s Replacement Adds to Cacophony Around Interest Rate Decision
item.description: The end of Jerome Powell’s term as Fed chair will give President Trump his biggest opportunity yet to reshape the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Naming a new Federal Reserve chair will be President Trump’s biggest opportunity yet to reshape the central bank.

item.title: Tony Dokoupil Is Named Anchor of ‘CBS Evening News’
item.description: He replaces John Dickerson and Maurice DuBois in one of the most high-profile decisions of Bari Weiss’s early tenure as the network’s editor in chief.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Dia Dipasupil/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tony Dokoupil is a veteran TV journalist who joined CBS as a correspondent in 2016.

item.title: Sophie Kinsella, ‘Confessions of a Shopaholic’ Author, Dies at 55
item.description: Writing under a pseudonym, Madeleine Wickham cultivated an international following for her series centered on a young woman addicted to shopping.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Sandra Mickiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British author Madeleine Wickham in 2024. Under the pen name Sophie Kinsella, she wrote nine “Shopaholic” novels, which sold tens of millions of copies and were translated into dozens of languages.

item.title: Why Markets Are Getting Anxious About the Fed
item.description: The central bank is widely expected to lower its benchmark lending rate on Wednesday. But investors are worried about what comes afterward.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shadow of President Trump could loom over Jay Powell, the Fed chair, at today’s meeting.

item.title: I.M.F. Prods China, Gently, on Its Weak Currency
item.description: Caught between Beijing and the Trump administration, the International Monetary Fund offered mild criticism of China for relying too heavily on exports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the I.M.F., said on Wednesday that China’s currency should appreciate.

item.title: Trump Administration Rules Threaten Nobel Prizes Won by Immigrants
item.description: As three immigrants claim Nobel Prizes in science for the United States this year, experts warn that immigration crackdowns could undo American innovation.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: The Fed Cut Rates Again but Deep Divisions Cloud Path Ahead
item.description: The central bank’s decision to lower interest rates for a third straight meeting was highly contentious, reflecting an internal divide that will likely limit how much borrowing costs will fall next year.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: 5 New Chocolate Shops in Paris to Try Out
item.description: French culinary legends and award-winning upstarts are expanding the city’s offerings. Here are five.
item.dc:creator: Seth Sherwood and Camille McOuat

item.title: Coupang C.E.O. Resigns in Fallout Over Massive South Korean Data Breach
item.description: Coupang said Park Dae-jun would step down to accept “grave responsibility” for the leak that exposed information on nearly 34 million customer accounts.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Yonhap News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Coupang’s chief executive, Park Dae-jun, making a public apology last month over the data breach.

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Fabian Bimmer/Reuters
item.media:description: On a production line of the Dutch semiconductor company Nexperia in Hamburg, Germany, last year. Dutch officials seized the company in September.

item.title: Taiwan Invokes National Security Law to Protect TSMC Trade Secrets
item.description: An executive left TSMC for Intel. Taiwan’s government says that could threaten its national security.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The authorities in Taiwan are taking a stronger hand in protecting the prized technology of the chip maker TSMC.

item.title: The Battle for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Nicole Sperling, a Times reporter who covers Hollywood and the streaming revolution, breaks down the competing bids from Netflix and Paramount to buy Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling, Edward Vega, Laura Salaberry, Jon Hazell and Chris Orr

item.title: FDA Expands Covid Vaccine Inquiry to Adult Deaths
item.description: The agency claimed that 10 children’s deaths were linked to the shots, although it did not release evidence to support the assertions.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Plans to Scrutinize 5 Years of Social Media History for Foreign Tourists
item.description: Even visitors from countries like Britain and France, whose citizens don’t need visas, would have to share five years’ worth of social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Visitors from countries in the visa waiver program would also be required to share a range of other information, including email addresses from the last decade.

item.title: Stephen Miller’s Stock Sale Raises Questions, Ethics Experts Say
item.description: Mr. Miller, one of President Trump’s top advisers, sold shares in the mining company MP Materials following a lucrative deal between the company and the government.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, one of the president’s top advisers, sold shares of a mining company after it had begun negotiations with the government, raising concerns among ethics experts.

item.title: Trump Seeks to Expand His Powers by Taking a Role in Warner Bros. Battle
item.description: The move comes as the Supreme Court also appears poised to put antitrust enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission under his control.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Warner Bros. Studios complex in Burbank, Calif.

item.title: Why Trump Accounts, as Currently Planned, Risk Leaving Out Many Children
item.description: Michael and Susan Dell are donating $6.25 billion to American children via the accounts, but the details matter.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller and Jonah Smith
item.media:credit: Gary Settle
item.media:description: Researchers suggest enrolling children automatically, but that’s not the current plan.

item.title: USA Today’s Top Editor Departs, the Second in Less Than Two Years
item.description: Caren Bohan, who was named editor in chief in September 2024, will no longer continue in her role “effective immediately,” the company told employees.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Aaron M. Sprecher, via Associated Press
item.media:description: USA Today is the flagship paper of USA Today Company, the nation’s largest newspaper publisher, with 200 local papers across 42 states.

item.title: Netflix and Paramount Battle for Warner Bros. — Have We Seen This Show Before?
item.description: The tug of war for Warner Bros. Discovery echoes an earlier clash of media titans.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The contest between Paramount and Netflix for Warner Bros. Discovery is a mirror image of a struggle decades ago for control of Paramount.

item.title: Mackenzie Scott Announces $7 Billion of Giving This Year
item.description: The philanthropist known for donating to historically Black colleges and nonprofits working on climate change offered the news by updating an October blog post.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The philanthropist MacKenzie Scott.

item.title: Some Teens Are on Social Media ‘Almost Constantly,’ Survey Says
item.description: The new Pew report also found that two-thirds of teens said they had used an A.I. chatbot.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Cruise Passenger Was Served 33 Drinks Before Deadly Encounter With Crew, Suit Says
item.description: Michael Virgil, 35, became agitated on a Royal Caribbean ship and was restrained by at least five crew members, including some who stood on his back, before he died, the medical examiner said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Navigator of the Seas in 2021. Michael Virgil and his family were aboard this ship when he died in December 2024.

item.title: Wall Street Is Shaking Off Fears of an A.I. Bubble. For Now.
item.description: The valuations of some artificial intelligence companies are approaching those of the dot-com boom. But investors worry that pulling money from today’s market risks future gains.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Nvidia’s China Lobbying Wins Big. But the True Payoff is Less Certain.
item.description: President Trump’s move fulfills a major goal of the chipmaker. But the move faces opposition in Washington — and uncertainty in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lobbying efforts by Jensen Huang, C.E.O. of Nvidia, appear to have paid off in a big way.

item.title: Trump Eases Limits on Nvidia Exports to China at ‘Critical Moment’
item.description: President Trump said Nvidia can export some chips. But years of U.S. restrictions have propelled China to make everything it needs for advanced A.I.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: John G Mabanglo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nvidia has argued that blocking access to its chips has only spurred Chinese companies to improve faster.

item.title: Same Product, Same Store, but on Instacart, Prices Might Differ
item.description: The findings are the latest example of how the notion of a single price is breaking down in the digital age, a trend economists say could be pushing up some prices.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: In tests in four cities across the country, nearly 200 volunteers checked prices on 20 grocery items on Instacart. They found differences in item after item.

item.title: Supreme Court Struggles With How to Insulate the Federal Reserve From Politics
item.description: The president seemed poised for a big Supreme Court win letting him remove officials without cause. But the justices appeared to struggle with how to insulate the Federal Reserve from politics.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has mused about trying to fire Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, but he has not followed through. Indeed, no president has sought to remove a member of the Fed board without cause.

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Whether to Lift Campaign Finance Limits
item.description: The dispute before the court involved a Republican effort to lift limits on how much money political parties can spend in coordination with candidates.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2010, in the landmark case Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court struck down legal limits on independent political spending by corporations and unions.

item.title: These Travel Influencers Don’t Want Freebies. They’re A.I.
item.description: Social media posts by A.I.-created travel avatars cost far less to produce, yet look and sound real. Human influencers worry they’re being elbowed out.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed

item.title: Trump Defends Tariffs Amid Growing Concerns Over Affordability
item.description: The president rolled out a $12 billion bailout for farmers as he makes the case that his policy is working — or will soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The president announced $12 billion in bailout money for America’s farmers who have been battered in large part by his trade policies.

item.title: Federal Judge Finds Trump’s Halt on Wind Energy Is Illegal
item.description: The president ordered a stop to permits for all wind farms on federal lands and waters. A judge called that “capricious.”
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vineyard Wind Farm, about 15 miles south of the coast of Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts.

item.title: Trump Clears Sale of More Powerful Nvidia A.I. Chips to China
item.description: Approval for the H200 chip followed months of haggling between tech industry backers and defense hawks.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration wants to encourage Chinese companies to use Nvidia’s H200 chip while limiting sales of the company’s newest chips, known as Blackwell.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel’s ABC Deal Is Extended Through May 2027
item.description: “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” became a flashpoint about free speech in the country after it was temporarily suspended this year.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Randy Holmes/Disney, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jimmy Kimmel’s show was briefly suspended by ABC in September because of comments he made about the man accused of killing Charlie Kirk.

item.title: Donald E. Petersen, 97, Who Rescued Ford Motor Co., Is Dead
item.description: An ex-Marine and a 40-year company veteran, he turned a nearly bankrupt money loser into the world’s most profitable automaker.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Jim Russell/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Donald E. Petersen, foreground, in 1981 touring a Philco-Ford of Canada factory with the plant manager, Bill Quindlin. Mr. Petersen, who spent 40 years with Ford, helped develop the Mustang, Thunderbird, LTD, Maverick and Continental Mark III.

item.title: A.I. Videos Have Flooded Social Media. No One Was Ready.
item.description: Apps like OpenAI’s Sora are fooling millions of users into thinking A.I. videos are real, even when they include warning labels.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Stands in the Middle as Netflix and Paramount Vie for a Megadeal
item.description: The president has shattered norms by pledging to “be involved” in the regulatory fate of a transaction that could reshape the news and entertainment industries.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has often relished pitting rivals against each other, from his “Apprentice” TV boardroom to the West Wing.

item.title: Jared Kushner Is Part of Paramount’s Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Mr. Kushner’s private equity fund is one of the many groups helping Paramount mount a hostile bid to buy the group, whose holdings include CNN.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner founded his private equity firm, Affinity Partners, after President Trump’s first term and faced scrutiny over its deep reliance on the Saudi sovereign wealth fund.
